channel.title: The Increment Operator: ++

item.title: The Increment Operator: ++
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:18, topic:397572”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=494712.msg3618164#msg3618164 date=1307157034]

[quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=494712.msg3618159#msg3618159 date=1307156740]

no it isn’t, don’t post if you don’t know what you’re talking about

I didn’t make an example on my program, loops should increment right off the bat. Alright ignore my comment; but don’t be an idiot and say I don’t know what I am talking about because looking at your examples you shouldn’t be talking.
[/quote]No, they never increment right off the bat. Ever. And if there are flaws in my example, feel free to point them out

Helpful hints are nice, my context was wrong but saying I don’t know what I am saying is taking it to a generality. One of many causes of flaming.
[/quote]I said you didn’t know what you were talking about because you gave someone an incorrect answer, which I find to be worse than flaming. And you never gave me a reason to think you do know what you’re talking about… :rolleyes: But considering you did the same thing to me I have no sympathy, even if it was just retaliation. Now, if you can think of a real example (I sure can’t) where it would make a difference besides what I said earlier,

The only time it ever matters is when you are doing operations in the same expression/line

please post it so we can all see.[/quote]

It matters when you are accessing methods also, if that was not included under ‘expressions’ because I don’t think that it is.

Read full topic

item.title: The Increment Operator: ++
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

no it isn’t, don’t post if you don’t know what you’re talking about

EDIT - in case you dont understand, the increment part of a for loop is done AFTER each iteration of the loop, so it doesn’t increment yet

Read full topic

item.title: The Increment Operator: ++
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

Epic Steve:

I’ve known about ++var but I’ve never really found a reason to use it over var++

for(int pos = 0; pos < array.length; ++pos);

Is the equivalent of:

for(int pos = 1; pos < arrays.length; pos++);

Read full topic

item.title: The Increment Operator: ++
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

n10si t:

is it bad that i didn’t even know you could do ++variable

Avoid using it with array indices. You’ll probably get an ArrayIndexOutOfBounds exception if you don’t check the value before hand.

[quote=“sinisoul, post:5, topic:397572”]Pre-incremental operator/Post-Incremental operator. Pre/Post in the scope of the action.

All you have to think it as.[/quote]

he knows what it is, he needed it explaining

Read full topic

item.title: The Increment Operator: ++
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

Pre-incremental operator/Post-Incremental operator. Pre/Post in the scope of the action.

All you have to think it as.

Read full topic

item.title: The Increment Operator: ++
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

var++ and ++var are equvalent to var = var + 1;

The only difference is when it’s used for other things. The easiest way to think about it is

++var sets var to var += 1, then it returns the current value.
var++ returns the current value, then sets var to var += 1.

Read full topic

item.title: The Increment Operator: ++
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

Okay so it is changing foo because it is adding onto foo. Alright I think I got it. Thanks for clearing that up. <3

Read full topic

item.title: The Increment Operator: ++
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

when you perform the increment operator onto a variable, it assigns a new value to the variable, even if it is in an assignment itself

your code is basically:

int foo = 0; foo = foo + 1; //or += 1 int bar = foo;

if you had done foo++ instead of ++foo, it would be

int foo = 0; int bar = foo; foo = foo + 1; //or += 1

and the output would have been
foo is: 1
bar is: 0

Read full topic

item.title: The Increment Operator: ++
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

Okay I am reading a tutorial on Java and it is discussing the increment operator. I cannot get my head around this. It just doesn’t make sense to me. Maybe it is the terms they are using, I am not sure. Here is what they have.

The increment operator ++ increments the value of its operand, and returns the result. The operator may appear before or after the variable.

If it appears before the variable, it is known as a pre-increment, and the increment happens before the assignment.

[code=Java]int foo = 0;
int bar = ++foo;

System.out.println("foo is: " + foo);
System.out.println("bar is: " + bar);
[/code]

foo is: 1
bar is: 1

Now my thoughts would be that since the increment is before foo on int bar, it would be like 1 + foo = bar, right?
Now it said that foo is 0. How the hell did it get to 1. Also is my thoughts about the increment right?

Read full topic
